vidtrack module¶

vidtrack.brightest(frame, n, bgmask=None)[source]¶

Returns the locations of the brightest n spots in the frame This isn’t quite working right and I’m not sure why...

vidtrack.candidatePoints(f)[source]¶

For an image file, yields (redPoints, greenPoints) for each frame

vidtrack.countChannel(img, pt, radius, channel)[source]¶
vidtrack.dist(pt1, pt2)[source]¶
vidtrack.findBackground(f, alpha)[source]¶

A basic wrapper for an OpenCV function that creates a static averaged image as the ‘background’ which will be subtracted out of subsequent frames

vidtrack.findCenters(data)[source]¶

For the (redPoint, greenPoint), finds the center of the two LED’s and returns them as (x, y) coords

vidtrack.frames(videoFile)[source]¶

Generator for frames from a video file. Yields (frameNum, totalFrames, frame) tuples. FrameNum starts from 1.

vidtrack.interpolate(x, y, alpha)[source]¶
vidtrack.minDist(pt, pts)[source]¶
vidtrack.mostColorful(channels, n, channel, bgmask=None)[source]¶

Channels should be output of cv2.split(img). Returns the locations of the n most pure examples of the specified channel. Values for channel number depend on your image format, but usually:

  • 0 = blue
  • 1 = green
  • 2 = red
vidtrack.processVideo(f)[source]¶
vidtrack.reviewCoords(data, f)[source]¶

This simply plays the video back frame by frame superimposing the points from the rest of the function onto it. It allows the user to click to change the point if it seems to be deviating too far.

vidtrack.run()[source]¶
vidtrack.simpleComponents(img)[source]¶

input: b/w image output: generator of (pos, area) tuples

vidtrack.simpleInterpolate(data)[source]¶

A function to remove outliers and interpolate empty frames from using the surrounding frames

vidtrack.writeCSV(data)[source]¶
